tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: ASoIaF Question #702: What is up with Umma the cook at the House of Black and White? Why does she have a name?  “Like Arya, the...
body:
ASoIaF Question #702: What is up with Umma the cook at the House of Black and White? Why does she have a name? 

“Like Arya, the waif lived below the temple, along with three acolytes, two serving men, and a cook called Umma. Umma liked to talk as she worked, but Arya could not understand a word she said. The others had no names, or did not choose to share them. One serving man was very old, his back bent like a bow. The second was red-faced, with hair growing from his ears.” - Arya II, AFfC

Arya is the one to give the names to the people around her at the HoBaW, but Umma already comes with one. Is she like an unofficial member? Or did none of them know how to cook so they chose someone to figure it out? On top of that Umma is the only other person we see that names people like Arya does. 

“No stick was better than a pair of eyes. It was good to have, though, so she always kept it close. Umma had taken to calling her Stick, but names did not matter. She was her. No one. I am no one. Just a blind girl, just a servant of Him of Many Faces.” - The Blind Girl, ADwD

Part of Arya’s issue with becoming No One is that she can’t really stop herself from forming attachments and bringing those associations with her. When she is being No One the waif and the kindly man are still referred to as such, she never changes it to other things. To everyone else in the HoBaW Arya is always No One when she comes back, but Umma gives her a name. Umma does not seem to be a No One, so who/what is she?

Arya :*about Gendry* He's not my boyfriend.
Jaqen : What is he, then? Your brother?
Arya : Oh, we have a comedian! What, did you...
body:
Arya :*about Gendry* He's not my boyfriend.
Jaqen : What is he, then? Your brother?
Arya : Oh, we have a comedian! What, did you eat clown for breakfast?
Jaqen : Wonderful. Our first fight.

blog.name: arsenicandfinelace
blog.title: Arsenic and Fine Lace
blog.description: Everything I say, I say from a place of sleep deprivation.

body:
S8 Wishlist 24/?

*Arya does something nice for Tyrion*

Tyrion: I’ll have to repay you for this.

Arya: You have nothing that I want.

Tyrion: I’m sure that’s not true. Let’s see. Ah!

Tyrion: Podrick.

Podrick: Yes, my lord?

Tyrion: Go talk to Gendry.

Podrick: What about?

Tyrion: *stares*

Podrick: *turning red* Yes, my lord.

Arya: ???

Tyrion: Oh, you’ll see.

*the next morning*

*Arya staggers in, looking wrecked*

Tyrion: Goodness, look at you. You look like you didn’t get a moment’s sleep.

Arya: *weakly pats Tyrion on shoulder*

Arya: We’re- we’re good.

Arya: *sits down gingerly*

Everyone else: ???

Tyrion: A Lannister always pays his debts.

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: It’s pretty solidly established in ASoIaF verse that Arya does not look like Cat [Arya I, AGoT]. Like to the point that Arya...
body:
It’s pretty solidly established in ASoIaF verse that Arya does not look like Cat [Arya I, AGoT]. Like to the point that Arya once thought she was a bastard [Arya I, AGoT] and Sansa thought she was a changeling [Sansa I, AGoT].

I kind of need Arya to meet up with the Blackfish or Edmure or someone to tell her that she has some resemblance of her mother. Like she has Cat’s smile or something.

I kind of need Arya to meet up with the Blackfish or Edmure or someone to tell her that she has some resemblance of her mother. Like she has Cat’s smile or something.

blog.name: aqueenofmarble
blog.title: Do I Dare Disturb the Universe?

summary: “Who we are and who we need to be to survive are very different things.“
body:
“Who we are and who we need to be to survive are very different things.“

I love this quote by Bellamy and honestly people need to think about this before judging Arya and calling her a psychopath when all she does is trying to survive and dealing with her trauma without breaking apart. She is an 11yo girl who saw and experienced terrible things that no child should witness. We don‘t see people calling male characters psychopaths when they do similar questionable things to survive or for revenge. They are complex and misunderstood whereas female characters that are not always angels are immediately sociopathic or psychopathic. It‘s just misogynistic and unfair. Men and women should get the same treatment.

blog.name: my-arya-underfoot
blog.title: He killed the slave? That did not sound right
blog.description: Appreciation blog for Arya Stark, her bull headed blacksmith and House Stark. Both book and show content. Meta tagged "my [character/relationship name] meta" e.g. my Arya meta, my Gendrya meta, my Stark meta. Background art credit to Psycuror and profile pic credit to Juhee.

tags: if I could draw I'd draw it myself
summary: The giant was dangling a bloody corpse by one leg, the same way Arya used to dangle her doll when she was small, swinging it...
text: The giant was dangling a bloody corpse by one leg, the same way Arya used to dangle her doll when she was small, swinging it like a morningstar when menaced by vegetables.
source:
Jon, ADwD

Um, most adorable sentence in the entire series?!?! I just can’t escape the image of tiny, scrappy Arya defending herself against the evils of vegetables at every meal. (Spare a thought for poor Catelyn here). 

Guys, WHERE IS ALL THE ADORABLE FANART OF THIS?!?!

reblog.comment:
Jon, ADwD

Um, most adorable sentence in the entire series?!?! I just can’t escape the image of tiny, scrappy Arya defending herself against the evils of vegetables at every meal. (Spare a thought for poor Catelyn here). 

Guys, WHERE IS ALL THE ADORABLE FANART OF THIS?!?!

summary: One of these days people are going to get that Feminism isn’t about deciding what the right kind of women is, but is about...
body: One of these days people are going to get that Feminism isn’t about deciding what the right kind of women is, but is about creating an environment in which women’s choices have agency, can be put into action and are respected, not matter what those choices are.

reblog.comment: One of these days people are going to get that Feminism isn’t about deciding what the right kind of women is, but is about creating an environment in which women’s choices have agency, can be put into action and are respected, not matter what those choices are.

blog.name: theladymeera
blog.title: I'm So Salty I'm a Pickle
blog.description:
Daenerys was my first fave and she will be my last.

Danielle, US. Meera is the frog queen of my heart but I post more about my dragon queen Dany. Trying to be a happy person against the will of all these nihilistic men.

This is my ASOIAF/GOT side blog. My main is a-mountain-girl, my booklr is readingaway.

question: Arya Stark
answer:
general opinion: fall in a hole and die | don’t like them | eh | they’re fine I guess | like them! | love them | actual love of my life
hotness level: get away from me | meh | neutral | theoretically hot but not my type (she is a child) | pretty hot | gorgeous! | 10/10 would bang
hogwarts house: gryffindor | slytherin | ravenclaw | hufflepuff
best quality: My baby girl is one smart cookie, she also has the biggest heart (yeah that’s two qualities but they’re both the best)
worst quality: sometimes, in the course of human events, people get stabbed
ship them with: Gendry!
brotp them with: Jon, Bran, Daenerys, Meera, Gendry, Hot Pie, Ned Dayne, Sandor…
needs to stay away from: Knives, the Faceless Men, Lannisters, the Others, the Boltons
misc. thoughts: I’m so excited to see where her storyline goes in the books, especially since my theories are all over the place

Talk to me guys

blog.name: buttercuparry
blog.title: Warm Winter Sun
blog.description: If a 12 year old has to save the world then so be it!

summary: "She got her first look at the man she must kill later that morning as she wheeled her barrow through the cobbled streets that...
body:
“She got her first look at the man she must kill later that morning as she wheeled her barrow through the cobbled streets that fronted on the Purple Harbor. He was an old man, well past fifty. He has lived too long, she tried to tell herself. Why should he have so many years when my father had so few? But Cat of the Canals had no father, so she kept that thought to herself.”

You know a lot of times people in the got/asoiaf fandom have portrayed Arya as this cold hearted killer who can kill anyone without batting an eyelid. Now I am not trying to be that dick who tells people how they should or shouldn’t potray a character in their own fanworks. But the thing is I personally don’t agree with it. Because I don’t think that she is anything like that. Like let’s take the above excerpt for an example. Here we see Arya observing the man who is going to be her very first “kill” as a novice of the HoBaW. Now what I find interesting here is how she desperately tries to come up with a valid reason about why she should be killing off this man. She tries to tell herself that the man is well past fifty and has lived long enough. She even thinks about how her father never got to live that long. This seems to be a half hearted try from Arya to make the man’s impending doom justifiable to herself. She fails to do so of course and thus tries to chanel in her anger.

“She even smiled at him. Sometimes a smile was all you needed to make them stop and buy. The old man did not smile back. He scowled at her and went on past, sloshing through a puddle. The splash wet her feet. He has no courtesy, she thought, watching him go. His face is hard and mean.”

What I find peculiar here is how Arya takes an offence at this man’s behaviour. Now please keep in mind that I am only saying this in reference to what happened the last time she was disguised as the Cat of the canals. At that time the Ibbenese whalers treated her almost the same way as this man and yet she did not think about them twice. Another thing that I want to point out is that after a few lines from this paragraph we see her call the man ‘evil’ based on his appearance. This is a direct contradiction to her character. Because Arya has never been the one to judge a person based on his/her outward appearance. In fact she has always tried to look at what lies beyond the surface. So I feel like Arya is deliberately trying to make herself believe that the man is evil. And it must be so because she fears that she is assassinating an innocent person. ( We even see her asking the Kindly Man if the Gods have judged this man! )

The concept of death has always been traumatising to Arya. In fact she has nightmares about killing the stable boy, Dareon and the Tickler. So it strikes me odd that she should claim that the man will thank her for a gift from the Many faced. I think that Arya is feeling guilty here and is therefore trying to tell herself that she is not doing anything wrong. It is only after she hears about how the man is cheating the widows and the children of the unfortunate seafarers out of their insurance money that she finally devises a plan to kill him.

Cat understood. One of them must hate him. One of them came to the House of Black and White and prayed for the god to take him. She wondered who it had been, but the kindly man would not tell her. “It is not for you to pry into such matters,” he said. “Who are you?”

“No one.”

“No one asks no questions.” He took her hands. “If you cannot do this thing, you need only say so. There is no shame in that. Some are made to serve the Many-Faced God and some are not. Say the word, and I shall lift this task from you.”

“I will do it. I said I would. I will.”

I like the implication of Arya trying to know about the person who has prayed for the gift. I also like how the Kindly Man says that the faceless men do not ask questions. But Arya is no faceless man and therefore she is always going to ask questions. She is not a heartless killer either. No matter how much some people claim her to be an “empty husk of herself”. The emotions that she goes through here is a proof of that.

reblog.comment:
“She got her first look at the man she must kill later that morning as she wheeled her barrow through the cobbled streets that fronted on the Purple Harbor. He was an old man, well past fifty. He has lived too long, she tried to tell herself. Why should he have so many years when my father had so few? But Cat of the Canals had no father, so she kept that thought to herself.”

You know a lot of times people in the got/asoiaf fandom have portrayed Arya as this cold hearted killer who can kill anyone without batting an eyelid. Now I am not trying to be that dick who tells people how they should or shouldn’t potray a character in their own fanworks. But the thing is I personally don’t agree with it. Because I don’t think that she is anything like that. Like let’s take the above excerpt for an example. Here we see Arya observing the man who is going to be her very first “kill” as a novice of the HoBaW. Now what I find interesting here is how she desperately tries to come up with a valid reason about why she should be killing off this man. She tries to tell herself that the man is well past fifty and has lived long enough. She even thinks about how her father never got to live that long. This seems to be a half hearted try from Arya to make the man’s impending doom justifiable to herself. She fails to do so of course and thus tries to chanel in her anger.

“She even smiled at him. Sometimes a smile was all you needed to make them stop and buy. The old man did not smile back. He scowled at her and went on past, sloshing through a puddle. The splash wet her feet. He has no courtesy, she thought, watching him go. His face is hard and mean.”

What I find peculiar here is how Arya takes an offence at this man’s behaviour. Now please keep in mind that I am only saying this in reference to what happened the last time she was disguised as the Cat of the canals. At that time the Ibbenese whalers treated her almost the same way as this man and yet she did not think about them twice. Another thing that I want to point out is that after a few lines from this paragraph we see her call the man ‘evil’ based on his appearance. This is a direct contradiction to her character. Because Arya has never been the one to judge a person based on his/her outward appearance. In fact she has always tried to look at what lies beyond the surface. So I feel like Arya is deliberately trying to make herself believe that the man is evil. And it must be so because she fears that she is assassinating an innocent person. ( We even see her asking the Kindly Man if the Gods have judged this man! )

The concept of death has always been traumatising to Arya. In fact she has nightmares about killing the stable boy, Dareon and the Tickler. So it strikes me odd that she should claim that the man will thank her for a gift from the Many faced. I think that Arya is feeling guilty here and is therefore trying to tell herself that she is not doing anything wrong. It is only after she hears about how the man is cheating the widows and the children of the unfortunate seafarers out of their insurance money that she finally devises a plan to kill him.

“No one.”

“No one asks no questions.” He took her hands. “If you cannot do this thing, you need only say so. There is no shame in that. Some are made to serve the Many-Faced God and some are not. Say the word, and I shall lift this task from you.”

“I will do it. I said I would. I will.”

I like the implication of Arya trying to know about the person who has prayed for the gift. I also like how the Kindly Man says that the faceless men do not ask questions. But Arya is no faceless man and therefore she is always going to ask questions. She is not a heartless killer either. No matter how much some people claim her to be an “empty husk of herself”. The emotions that she goes through here is a proof of that.

blog.name: aqueenofmarble
blog.title: Do I Dare Disturb the Universe?

summary: Ok but I need a scene in s8 like in Half-blood Prince with an unconscious Arya lying on the bed and Jon beside her. And Arya...
body: Ok but I need a scene in s8 like in Half-blood Prince with an unconscious Arya lying on the bed and Jon beside her. And Arya starts to say something and Jon thinks she wants him but she says „Gendry“ and Sansa, Davos, Bran and Jon all look at him. And Jon steps aside so Gendry can sit beside Arya and Davos says „I think she‘s in safe hands“ and they all leave the room but Jon and Gendry share a last glance and Jon gives him a smile meaning he approves and Gendry lets out a breath he‘s been holding for ten minutes.

summary: Yes, Arya and Sandor have similar facial features, but let's be real: the main reason everyone thought those two are related was...
body: Yes, Arya and Sandor have similar facial features, but let’s be real: the main reason everyone thought those two are related was that both had a bad case of BRF.
